member.name: T:DataAccess.Row
member.summary: Represents a row within a The Row may or may not be mutable, depending on whether the table is mutable.

member.summary: Lookup value by column name. Returns emtpy string if column name is not valid.
member.returns: value or empty string

member.summary: Plural version of
member.returns: enumeration of corresponding values

member.name: P:DataAccess.Row.Values
member.summary: ordered collection of values for this row. The ordering matches the column ordering.

member.name: P:DataAccess.Row.ColumnNames
member.summary: Column names for the table containing this row. This is a parallel collection to

member.name: P:DataAccess.Row.DebugValues
member.summary: Debug helper to show all values.

member.name: P:DataAccess.Row.Item(System.String)
member.summary: Lookup value by column name. Throws if column name is not valid.
member.returns: the value in the given column

member.name: T:DataAccess.TextReaderDataTable
member.summary: Stream rows from a file. This is ideal for large read-only files.

member.name: T:DataAccess.DataTable
member.summary: Represents a table of data. This is primary an IEnumerable{Row} collection. The table may be just read-only streaming over the rows, which is ideal for large files of millions of rows. Or it may have loaded the entire table into memory, which can be ideal for mutation.

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTable.RowsAs``1
member.summary: Enumeration of rows as strongly types. The default implementation here is to just to parse the results of .
member.returns: enumeration of rows as strongly typed object

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTable.HasColumnName(System.String)
member.summary: Return true if the table has the given column name. Comparison is case insensitive.
member.param: name of column to look for.
member.returns: true iff the column is present. False if name is null.

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTable.GetColumnIndex(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Get the index for the column. This can be used for an optimized column lookup when streaming across rows.
member.param: name of column to look for
If the column is nmissing, either throw an exception or return index of -1

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTable.SaveToStream(System.IO.TextWriter)
member.summary: Save the table to the given stream, using a CSV format. The first line will be the headers, and then each subsequent line will be a row. This will escape characters as needed.

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTable.SaveCSV(System.String)
member.summary: Save the table as a CSV to the given filename
member.param: filename on disk to save to.

member.name: P:DataAccess.DataTable.Name
member.summary: Name of this data table. The semantics of the name are determined by the function that creates the table. Name can also be empty. It could be a filename, an excel sheet name, a URL, or even a human readable description of how the table was created. Name is primarily a debugging tool. You can't programaticaly rely on the name property unless you created the table.

member.name: P:DataAccess.DataTable.ColumnNames
member.summary: Name of columns in the table. Columns should be case-insensitive. If this is a mutable table, columns may be added, removed, or reordered.

member.name: P:DataAccess.DataTable.Rows
member.summary: Enumeration of rows in the table. Each row has a (possibly empty) value for each column.

member.name: P:DataAccess.DataTable.New
member.summary: Provides access to extension methods for creating a table. Tables can be created in many ways, such as reading CSV files, building around .NET objects, filtering existing tables, etc.

member.name: T:DataAccess.EnumerableDataTable`1
member.summary: Create a streaming data table around an Ienumerable

member.name: T:DataAccess.AssertException
member.summary: Exception thrown on illegal user operation.

member.name: T:DataAccess.Dictionary2d`3
member.summary: 2d Dictionary, useful for spare storage. Implementation is not intended for large sizes. Rather, we expect this to be used for summarizing information.

member.name: P:DataAccess.Dictionary2d`3.Count
member.summary: Count of total entries in the collection

member.name: P:DataAccess.Dictionary2d`3.Item(`0,`1)
member.summary: lookup a value. Returns a default value if not found.
member.returns: value stored at the given key pair.

member.name: P:DataAccess.Dictionary2d`3.Key1
member.summary: Sorted enumeration of the first keyset.

member.name: P:DataAccess.Dictionary2d`3.Key2
member.summary: Sorted enumeration of the second keyset.

member.name: T:DataAccess.Analyze
member.summary: Analysis operations on tables, like joins, histogram, dup search, filter, etc. These handle large tables.

member.name: M:DataAccess.Analyze.Shred(DataAccess.DataTable,System.String,System.Func{System.String,System.IO.TextWriter})
member.summary: Given a potentially extremely large table, shred it into smaller CSV files based on the values in columnName. This can be very useful for easily building an index for a large file. For each unique value in column, funcCreateStream is invoked with that value to get a TextWriter. The csv is written to that writer. The ordering within each small file is preserved This stream based overload is useful when you need to avoid writing to the local file system (such as with Azure storage)
member.param: callback function to create a stream for each new table.
column name to use for shredding. You can use to see the variation in each column to determine a good column to use for shredding.

member.name: M:DataAccess.Analyze.Shred(DataAccess.DataTable,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Given a potentially extremely large table, shred it into smaller CSV files based on the values in columnName. This can be very useful for easily building an index for a large file. For each unique value in column, a CSV file is created and named string.Format(templateFilename, value). The ordering within each small file is preserved
member.param: column name to use for shredding. You can use to see the variation in each column to determine a good column to use for shredding.
template specifying filename of shredded files.

member.name: M:DataAccess.Analyze.Where(DataAccess.DataTable,System.Func{DataAccess.Row,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Apply a Where filter to a table. This can stream over large data and filter it down.
member.param: predicate to execute on each row
member.returns: a new table that copies out rows from from the source table

member.name: M:DataAccess.Analyze.Join(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{DataAccess.DataTable})
member.summary: Merge 2 datatables together assuming no common join key. This will collapse common columns, but keep all rows. This needs to deal with columns being in different orders
member.param: set of tables to merge together
member.returns: a merged table. The rows may be in a random order.

member.name: M:DataAccess.Analyze.Join(DataAccess.MutableDataTable,DataAccess.MutableDataTable,System.String)
member.summary: Performs a full outer join on two in-memory tables and returns a new table. The number of rows in the resulting table is the sum of rows from each source table. The number of columns in teh new table is the sum of columns in the the source tables minus 1 (since the join column is redundant)
member.param: column name to join on. Both tables must have this column name.
member.returns: a new table

member.name: M:DataAccess.Analyze.SampleTopN(DataAccess.DataTable,System.Int32)
member.summary: Return a sample that's the top N records from a table. This is useful to sample a large table and then save the sample.
member.param: positive value specifying number of rows to copy from from source table
member.returns: The topN rows from the source table.

member.name: M:DataAccess.Analyze.AsHistogram(DataAccess.DataTable,System.String)
member.summary: Extract column as a histogram, sorted in descending order by frequency.
member.returns: collection of tuples, where each tuple is a value and the count of that value within the column

member.name: M:DataAccess.Analyze.AsHistogram(DataAccess.DataTable,System.Int32)
member.summary: Extract column as a histogram, sorted in descending order by frequency.
member.returns: collection of tuples, where each tuple is a value and the count of that value within the column

member.name: M:DataAccess.Analyze.GetColumnValueCounts(DataAccess.DataTable,System.Int32)
member.summary: Produces a table where each row is the number of unique values in a source column, followed by the top N occurences in that column.
member.param: number of top N occurences to include in the summary table
member.returns: a summary table

member.name: M:DataAccess.Analyze.SelectDuplicates(DataAccess.DataTable,System.String[])
member.summary: Find all rows that have dups for the given columns. This uses a multi-pass algorithm to operate on a large data file.
member.param: set of columns to compare to look for duplicates
member.returns: a table that's a subset of the original table

member.name: F:DataAccess.Analyze.GetTempFileName
member.summary: For azure usage, allow hooking the function used to create temporary files

member.name: T:DataAccess.Column
member.summary: Column from an in-memory data table. Columns know their length and directly expose their values as a mutable array.

member.name: M:DataAccess.Column.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Create a new column. Caller must still add this into a table.
member.param: number of rows in the column. This will set the length of the Values array

member.name: M:DataAccess.Column.ToString
member.summary: Provide summary string representation for this column

member.name: M:DataAccess.Column.CheckIsEmpty
member.summary: Check if this column has any data in it.
member.returns: True iff all of the values are empty

member.name: P:DataAccess.Column.Name
member.summary: Name of the column. Operations on column names are case-insensitive.

member.name: P:DataAccess.Column.Values
member.summary: Values in this column.

member.name: T:DataAccess.RowExtension
member.summary: Extension methods for Row object

member.name: M:DataAccess.RowExtension.As``1(DataAccess.Row)
member.summary: Makes a best effort to parse the row into a strongly typed object. It's much faster to call DataTable.RowsAs[T] instead, because that will reuse parsing logic across rows. This does a case-insensitive match of the Target object's property names against the table's column names. Parse errors are ignored and may produce invalid results for the corresponding cell.
member.returns: an object representing the row

member.name: T:DataAccess.DataTableBuilder
member.summary: Empty class. Just exists to hang extension methods off.

member.name: T:DataAccess.DataTableBuilderExtensions
member.summary:
Provide extension methods for creating tables. Use extensions methods (instead of ctors) because they're discoverable and extendable. All extensions methods should follow the convention: - returning a table. - Use "Lazy" if the table is not in-memory.
Example usage: DataTable dt = DataTable.New.FromCsv()

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTableBuilderExtensions.ReadCsv(DataAccess.DataTableBuilder,System.String)
member.summary: Read an entire CSV file into memory.
member.param: filename of CSV file to load
member.returns: a mutable in-memory DataTable for the given CSV file

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTableBuilderExtensions.Read(DataAccess.DataTableBuilder,System.String)
member.summary: Read a file into memory. Infer the schema from the header row. Biased to CSV, but may handle tab delimeters too.
member.returns: a new in-memory table

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTableBuilderExtensions.Read(DataAccess.DataTableBuilder,System.IO.TextReader)
member.summary: Read a table from the stream into memory. Infer the schema from the header row. Biased to CSV, but may handle tab delimeters too.
member.returns: a new in-memory table

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTableBuilderExtensions.Read(DataAccess.DataTableBuilder,System.IO.TextReader,System.Char)
member.summary: Read a table from the stream into memory. Infer the schema from the header row. Biased to CSV, but may handle tab delimeters too.
member.param: delimiter characeter to use for separatior
member.returns: a new in-memory table

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTableBuilderExtensions.GetMutableCopy(DataAccess.DataTableBuilder,DataAccess.DataTable)
member.summary: Gets a mutable in-memory copy of the given data table.
member.param: source table that will get copied
member.returns: a new table

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTableBuilderExtensions.ReadSampleTopN(DataAccess.DataTableBuilder,System.String)
member.summary: Return an in-memory table that contains the topN rows from the table in the filename.
member.param: filename of table to load. Schema is inferred from header row.
member.returns: a in-memory table containing the topN rows from the supplied file.

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTableBuilderExtensions.ReadSampleTopN(DataAccess.DataTableBuilder,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Return an in-memory table that contains the topN rows from the table in the filename.
member.param: filename of table to load. Schema is inferred from header row.
reads the topN rows from the table.
member.returns: a in-memory table containing the topN rows from the supplied file.

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTableBuilderExtensions.ReadLazy(DataAccess.DataTableBuilder,System.String)
member.summary: Return a streaming data table over a file. This just reads a row at a time and avoids reading the whole table into memory. But it only provides sequential read-only access.
member.returns: a streaming data table for the given filename

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTableBuilderExtensions.ReadLazy(DataAccess.DataTableBuilder,System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Return a streaming data table over a stream. This just reads a row at a time and avoids reading the whole table into memory. But it only provides sequential read-only access.
member.param: input stream. Must be seekable and readable
member.returns: a streaming data table for the given filename

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTableBuilderExtensions.FromDictionary``2(DataAccess.DataTableBuilder,System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{``0,``1},System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Create an in-memory table with 2 columns (key and value), where each row is a KeyValuePair from the dictionary.
member.param: name for column that holds the dictionary keys
name for column that holds the dictionary values
member.returns: an in-memory table

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTableBuilderExtensions.From2dDictionary``3(DataAccess.DataTableBuilder,DataAccess.Dictionary2d{``0,``1,``2},System.String)
member.summary: Copy the 2d-dictionary into a in-memory table. This is ideal for creating a sparse table from a dictionary. Column names are inferred from key values. This adds a new column (in position 0) to label TKeyRow.
member.param: Name of the new column added which corresponds to TKeyRow.

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTableBuilderExtensions.FromTuple``2(DataAccess.DataTableBuilder,System.Tuple{``0,``1}[],System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Create an in-memory table from the tuple collection. Pass in column names since Tuple properties are just named Item1 and Item2.

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTableBuilderExtensions.FromEnumerable``1(DataAccess.DataTableBuilder,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Create an in-memory table where each row is an item in the enumeration. The columns are from the "flattened" properties of the T (not fields). The column names are inferred from T's property names.

member.name: M:DataAccess.DataTableBuilderExtensions.FromEnumerableLazy``1(DataAccess.DataTableBuilder,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Create a lazy table around the enumeration.

member.name: T:DataAccess.MutableDataTable
member.summary: Mutable tabular data. Entire table is loaded in memory, and exposes both column and row access. Table is stored in column major format, so supports efficient column operations like add, remove, and reorder. Also exposes row enumeration. Table can be mutated through either row or column views.

member.name: M:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.KeepColumns(System.String[])
member.summary: Remove all columns except for the ones listed. Allows case insensitive matching. Also reorders to match names.

member.name: M:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.GetColumn(System.String)
member.summary: Case-insensitive name lookup of a column.
member.param: name of column to look for
member.returns: null if column is not found

members.member:
Reorder a column.
name of column new position for column /// True means throw an exception if the column is missing. Else, nop if the column is missing

member.name: M:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.GetColumns(System.String[])
member.summary: Retrieve multiple columns matching the given names
member.returns: columns correpsonding to provided names

member.name: M:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.CreateColumn(System.String,System.Func{DataAccess.Row,System.String})
member.summary: Create a new column at the end of the table, and initialize the values for each row using the supplied function.
member.param: function to compute the value for this cell
member.returns: returns newly created column

member.name: M:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.CreateColumnFromMerging(System.String,System.String[])
member.summary: Merge each column into a new column. Use space as join character. This adds a new column. The existing columns are not removed.
member.returns: the newly created column

member.name: M:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.RenameColumn(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: rename a column from an old name to the new name
member.param: new name for the column. Must be a unique name

member.name: M:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.GetRow(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get a specific row by row-index.
member.returns: row at the given index

member.name: M:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.KeepRows(System.Func{DataAccess.Row,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Only keep rows where the predicate returns true
member.param: predicate to execute on each row

member.name: M:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.DeleteColumn(System.Int32)
member.summary: Remove column with the given index

member.name: M:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.DeleteColumnsAllowMissing(System.String[])
member.summary: Delete columns, ignores any column names that are missing.
member.param: names of rows to delete. Ignores if any of the names are missing.

member.name: M:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.DeleteColumns(System.String[])
member.summary: Remove columns with given names. This is the opposite of Throws if any of the names are missing.
member.param: names of rows to delete. Throws if any of the names are missing.

member.name: M:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.ApplyToColumn(System.String,System.Func{System.String,System.String})
member.summary: Apply a given function to every entry in a column This transforms the column in place.
member.param: function called once for each column value, replaces each cell in the column

member.name: P:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.Columns
member.summary: Return the set of columnns in this mutable table. Column represent the direct storage and are mutable.

member.name: P:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.ColumnNames
member.summary: Get the names of the columns, in the order they appear.

member.name: P:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.NumRows
member.summary: Return total number of rows in the table.

member.name: P:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.Rows
member.summary: Enumerate the rows in the table. The rows provide mutable access to the underlying storage

member.name: P:DataAccess.MutableDataTable.RowInMemory.Values
member.summary: Mutable implementation. Setting values can change original storage, just like columns.
